C'RIZZ: Why can't it just follow your string?
CHARLEY: Right. Anyway, er, which way do we go?
C'RIZZ: What? What did I say?
TIGGER: I suggest straight ahead.
EEYORE: May I repeat, we are in a maze. There is no straight ahead.
DOCTOR: This way, all of you.
EEYORE: I'm not sure about that third one of us.
DOCTOR: I don't know either of you.
EEYORE: You wish, old chap. Stuck with us, you are.
DOCTOR: Then you're stuck, as you put it, too. He came up with the string idea, don't forget.
EEYORE: Sooner or later one of us would have come up with it. We have the same mind, after all. It's the personalities that are different.
DOCTOR: Yes, I got that part.
EEYORE: You sound like me.
DOCTOR: I. Something about this whole situation is strange. Wrong, somehow.
EEYORE: I know what you mean. Slightly off.
DOCTOR: But I haven't quite worked out what it is.
EEYORE: Nor me. It's. Nothing fits together quite right, like a floor that looks even, but a marble dropped on it rolls into a corner.
DOCTOR: Exactly.
TIGGER: Like the rabbit.
EEYORE: Don't sneak up like that.
DOCTOR: What rabbit?
TIGGER: In the Garden of Curiosities. It was large, and humming. Also twirling.
EEYORE: If an animal's in a Garden of Curiosities, you should expect it to behave curiously.
TIGGER: No, it's not the behaviour that puzzles me, it's the rabbit itself. What's it doing here?
EEYORE: Twirling, you said.
TIGGER: And humming, but
EEYORE: Are you saying
TIGGER: Yes.
EEYORE: What's even a large rabbit doing here in this universe, on this particular planet?
DOCTOR: That sort of correspondence isn't impossible, of course, but it is suggestive.
TIGGER: Wrong somehow.
EEYORE: Slightly off.
DOCTOR: As if nothing quite fits.
CHARLEY: What are you three on about?
DOCTOR: Intuition. Tell me, Charley. Do you feel that this place is a bit off?
CHARLEY: A bit off? You are joking, aren't you? The whole place is tilted six ways from Sunday.
TIGGER: It's us, then.
EEYORE: It's our temporal connection.
DOCTOR: Which is impossible.
C'RIZZ: Sorry, er, has anyone heard the monster recently?
ALL DOCTORS: Ah.
CHARLEY: I don't like this at all. Why would it stop making any noise, unless it was sneaking up.
TIGGER: Pessimism is never useful. Let's look on the bright side.
EEYORE: There is no bright side, you idiot.
DOCTOR: Shh, shh, shh. It's bound to be tracking us by sound. Stay quiet.
C'RIZZ: How long do we stand like this?
CHARLEY: Until we think of a plan.
C'RIZZ: And how can we think of a plan if we can't talk to one another?
TIGGER: It's a paradox.
EEYORE: It is not a paradox, it's a dilemma. And I wish you would all shut up.
DOCTOR: There still isn't any sound of the creature. I think
DOCTOR: Run!
DOCTOR: Charley, where are you? Give me your hand.
CHARLEY: I'm here. Where's C'Rizz?
DOCTOR: Up ahead, He's got some speed on him. Fortunately our pursuer doesn't.
TIGGER: Perhaps we'll lose him.
CHARLEY: We don't seem to be. Doctor, did you see it?
EEYORE: Too busy running for my life.
DOCTOR: Why?
CHARLEY: It was a minotaur.
TIGGER: What?
CHARLEY: Don't stop, for God's sake.
DOCTOR: But that indicates that
CHARLEY: Come on!
WAYLAND: This way.
C'RIZZ: Who's that?
EEYORE: Who cares?
WAYLAND: Quickly, follow me. Through here. This corridor's hidden. He can't find us.
WAYLAND: (Breathless.
DOCTOR: Thank you.
CHARLEY: More cavern.
WAYLAND: Only for a few hundred yards, then we'll be out of here.
C'RIZZ: Who are you?
WAYLAND: My name is Wayland. I built this place.
CHARLEY: What in the name of heaven for?
WAYLAND: It was to protect our central control terminal for the system that runs our environment. For our surface life we have chosen a slow pace and simplicity.
DOCTOR: But you still want hot water and modern medicine.
WAYLAND: As you say. We had engineered for ourselves a workable combination of the technical and the natural, and then they came. They presented themselves as engineers with much to teach us in return for payment in calcium, which they use in some fashion to help propel their craft. Our mountains are full of calcite, so we struck a bargain. And it was true. They had extensive environmental shaping programmes that were far ahead of ours, only
DOCTOR: Only they took over.
WAYLAND: It was subtle at first, then we began to realise they'd infected everything. They installed their own central system in the middle of this labyrinth and sealed ours off so that we couldn't access it. We were
EEYORE: What do they look like?
WAYLAND: We never saw them. They communicated with us through robotic screens. We assume they were unable to survive on the planet itself.
EEYORE: Blast.
TIGGER: Do you think?
DOCTOR: It has to be them.
TIGGER: But there's no castle.
EEYORE: kro'Ka lied.
DOCTOR: I don't think so.
WAYLAND: I, I'm sorry?
CHARLEY: Don't mind them. They can go on like this for hours. I'm Charley Pollard, and this is C'Rizz, and those are the Doctors.
WAYLAND: Are they triplets?
C'RIZZ: In a way.
WAYLAND: How did you come here?
CHARLEY: We'd been travelling for a while, and needed a break. This looked like a pleasant place to stop.
WAYLAND: But how did you find yourselves in the maze?
CHARLEY: Sort of by accident.
WAYLAND: That's the way it is for everyone. I come every day to see if someone is trapped here.
C'RIZZ: Has anyone been killed?
WAYLAND: I'm afraid so. I never thought my creation would be put to this hideous use.
CHARLEY: Well, the monster can't live in the exact centre, or it would destroy what it was meant to protect.
WAYLAND: Yes. It guards only the perimeter.
DOCTOR: We may be able to help you.
WAYLAND: You? But you're strangers who don't even know this society. How can you?
TIGGER: I can't yet say. We may choose one way, we may choose another. You lose nothing by letting us try.
DOCTOR: You say your own control centre is now inaccessible.
WAYLAND: Sealed behind an impregnable door.
DOCTOR: Let's have a look at it.
TIGGER: C'Rizz, I think another visit to the Garden of Curiosities is in order. You should join us, Charley.
CHARLEY: But won't the others need your help?
TIGGER: If two of me can't unseal that door, three of me won't do much better. C'Rizz, you remember that sign.
C'RIZZ: I remember the Obelat.
TIGGER: Yes, I know. Very unpleasant. But we needn't go inside this time.
CHARLEY: What's the Obelat?
TIGGER: I've never seen one.
C'RIZZ: It's difficult to explain.
TIGGER: Ah, here we are, out at last. Let's be off, then. We'll be back shortly.
WAYLAND: Where are you going?
TIGGER: Fresh air. Been underground too long. We'll meet at the town square.
WAYLAND: I had hoped all of you would help.
EEYORE: Not to worry. One of us could probably do it on his head.
WAYLAND: Oh. Well then, this way.
WAYLAND: There. In the far wall.
DOCTOR: I see. It's a series of mathematical locks.
WAYLAND: The logarithms have baffled our best mathematicians.
DOCTOR: Hmm. I think we can do this.
WAYLAND: Can you really? Our whole world will rejoice.
EEYORE: Don't fetch the confetti just yet. This will take some time.
WAYLAND: I beg your pardon?
DOCTOR: Sorry, term of art in safe-cracking. He means that it will be a bit before we get inside.
WAYLAND: Oh, I see. I'll leave you to it. Would you like anything to eat or drink?
DOCTOR: No, thank you. We'll be fine.
DOCTOR: Small wonder they couldn't get in. Transcendental mathematics. Are you thinking what I'm thinking?
EEYORE: Yes, of course I am. This nitwit is trying to get us to break into our own Tardis.
CHARLEY: What is this place exactly?
TIGGER: It's peculiar. It appears to be a zoological park for unusual animals, some of them probably from off-world. But there are very few animals, unless most of them are nocturnal, and some of them are dangerous.
CHARLEY: Like this Obelat?
C'RIZZ: Yes.
CHARLEY: But that doesn't make sense. Surely the Obelat would kill the other animals? Doesn't sound as if that rabbit would be much of a match for it.
C'RIZZ: That hadn't occurred to me.
TIGGER: It occured to me.
CHARLEY: Well, of course. That's only one of the things about this planet that doesn't fit properly. That giant clock that the Doctor and I entered the maze through. I know it had no hands, but it was still obviously a clock. What's it doing here?
TIGGER: Yes, curious, isn't it. Speaking of which, here's the sign. Tell us what it says, will you, Charley?
CHARLEY: But you already know.
TIGGER: Just tell us, please.
CHARLEY: The Garden of Curiosities, like you said.
TIGGER: How can you read it?
CHARLEY: It's in English.
TIGGER: I read it in Gallifreyan.
C'RIZZ: It's Eutermesan, actually. What does this mean?
CHARLEY: That this whole world is an illusion!
TIGGER: I'm not sure that that's altogether the case, but certainly parts of it have been drawn from our minds. From Charley and possibly from me as well, the clock, the rabbit, the minotaur. From C'Rizz the Obelat and some of his native flora. It's a pity, really, this world seems so interesting. At least that nice red animal is real.
C'RIZZ: Do you mean that the other things aren't? That the Obelat could never have hurt us?
TIGGER: No, it could have hurt us quite badly, though how exactly I don't know. These aren't illusions but constructs. They're solid enough to be felt and do damage, but their original source is our minds.
CHARLEY: But why bother? They don't serve any purpose. In fact, the clock tipped us off
CHARLEY: that something odd was going on, which I doubt whoever's in charge wanted.
TIGGER: I think much of what we've seen are by-products of the creation of a more purposeful construct. Possibly the maze. The energy wasn't controlled properly and produced a few extras. And they're often not quite right. The spinning rabbit, the clock without hands.
CHARLEY: The Divergents did all this, didn't they.
TIGGER: I'm not sure. They certainly have the power. But the Divergents have been going out of their way to stay hidden. I can't see them allowing me near them. At least, not at this point.
C'RIZZ: In any case, you came here by accident. Or do you think they anticipated your Time sickness would guide you to this world?
TIGGER: They might have done, I suppose. But if they wanted me, I suppose they could just reach out and snatch me up. Why all this subterfuge?
CHARLEY: Perhaps we shouldn't have left the other two with Wayland.
DOCTOR: It'll be good to see the old girl again. How I've missed her.
EEYORE: More to the point, she's our way out of here. And out from under the Divergent's prying eye. Do you suppose they're behind this?
DOCTOR: I hope so. I'd like to make them tell me why they're doing all this. The manipulation, the shunting between zones, the mind games.
EEYORE: I presume we have something they want.
DOCTOR: You know, they could have just asked. A bit of civility and all this messing about would have been avoided.
EEYORE: We probably wouldn't have answered them.
DOCTOR: Yes, there is that. Ah well, onward and upward. One of the things they undoubtedly want is the secret of how the Tardis works, so we can't let them in this door.
EEYORE: And I don't think hanging about is a good idea.
DOCTOR: Should we just tip-toe quietly away?
KRO'KA: Doctor.
EEYORE: Good grief. This is all we need.
DOCTOR: Oh, hello, Kro'Ka. You're here, are you? I see you're invisible again.
KRO'KA: Doctor!
EEYORE: Let's skip the melodrama, shall we, and get to the point.
KRO'KA: I have fooled you all.
EEYORE: Still with the melodrama. Do I have to point out that if you had really fooled us, you'd be inside the Tardis now?
DOCTOR: Nonetheless, good job, Kro'Ka. Inventive in many ways. You were everyone we met, weren't you? I think there really is a town out there, but you've shielded them from us and from your constructs.
EEYORE: You followed me, didn't you, anxious to correct your little error of letting me come to the very planet on which the Tardis is hidden.
DOCTOR: And the only way you could keep your masters from killing you when they discovered your mistake was to trick me into opening the Tardis. Then you could deliver it to them as a prize, and all might be forgiven.
KRO'KA: You are very clever, Doctor, and yet you are in my power.
EEYORE: In my power. Spare me. Can you get yourself some fresh dialogue?
DOCTOR: I've always been in your power, Kro'Ka. You've tortured me and my friends, and shoved us through whatever portals you wanted.
KRO'KA: But now, you are completely in my power.
EEYORE: I can't stand any more of this. I'll just go over here while you two trade clich√©s.
DOCTOR: He's very sensitive to the cadence of vocabulary of everyday speech. So am I, actually, only not for the past several hours. By the way, did you split us in three, or was it the journey through the portal?
KRO'KA: I didn't do it, but it plays into my hands.
DOCTOR: You don't have hands.
KRO'KA: The three of you were foolish enough to split up, and now the weakest of you is isolated.
DOCTOR: The weakest?
KRO'KA: He is dreamy, abstracted, naive. He'll be easier to break.
DOCTOR: You're underestimating him, me, Kro'Ka. Some of my goofiest incarnations have been my sliest.
EEYORE: Hang on. Did you say break?
KRO'KA: I thought you weren't listening.
DOCTOR: Friend Kro'Ka has to get the secrets of the Tardis somehow, and since he can't get into it, I won't let you, you know.
KRO'KA: And how will you stop me?
DOCTOR: Kro'Ka!
EEYORE: Such a winning personality. He ought to run for dictator.
DOCTOR: We have to get out of here, intercept. Where's the sealed door gone?
EEYORE: Never mind that, where's the door to the hall gone?
DOCTOR: The whole room's dissolving.
EEYORE: Oh, terrific. What do you bet we end up in the labyrinth?
DOCTOR: Bother.
TIGGER: All right, here's the town square where we're all supposed to meet. I want the two of you to stay here in case anyone shows up. I shall go back into the administration building and find the others.
CHARLEY: Oh, that's a terrible idea.
TIGGER: No, it isn't.
C'RIZZ: It doesn't strike me as the wisest course.
TIGGER: Wisdom isn't what's wanted here. We need spontaneity, which fortunately is my strong suit.
CHARLEY: The others are already who knows where. I don't want to lose track of you as well.
TIGGER: Good point. Here, take this ball of string. I'll tie the free end to my belt.
CHARLEY: That's not what
TIGGER: Cheerio!
CHARLEY: (distant) Oh, hang on, Doctor!
TIGGER: Sorry. Excuse me. I beg your pardon. Oh dear, was that your. I see, never mind. Ah, here we are.
TIGGER: No one home. At least, no one answering the door.
TIGGER: Hello? Here I am, chicken for the plucking! Fish for the frying. Goose for the er, the er er, thing you do with geese. Oh, come on then, isn't this the part where someone with a gun appears and explains everything? Not that I haven't worked out most of it. All right, wrong approach. Let's try going through a mysterious door.
KRO'KA: What was that phrase you used to me earlier, Doctor? Oh, yes. Got you.
TIGGER: Will you let go of my collar?
KRO'KA: All in good time.
TIGGER: Now is an excellent time.
KRO'KA: What's that string?
TIGGER: Goodness, where did all that come from? You never know what you'll pick up on the street. Here, I'll just snap it. Oh dear, you're visible again. Please vanish. Now!
KRO'KA: None of that, Doctor. We're not in your mind now. Here, I am in control.
TIGGER: Where are the others?
KRO'KA: Trapped in the maze with the monster.
TIGGER: And I suppose I'm to join them.
KRO'KA: No, Doctor. I have special plans for you.
TIGGER: Unpleasant plans?
KRO'KA: Of course.
TIGGER: Yes, they generally are. Forgive me for getting personal, Kro'Ka, but you really are a bit of a dog's breakfast. Couldn't you put up one of those projections you use earlier?
KRO'KA: So you've guessed.
TIGGER: Guessing had nothing to do with it. You are simply not as clever as you think. There were a number of anomalies in the world you constructed that gave you away. All right, I admit, not you specifically, but it was obvious someone was manipulating the situation.
KRO'KA: Anomalies?
TIGGER: Such as that giant twirling rabbit.
KRO'KA: Rabbit?
TIGGER: Also a green hamster. You mean you didn't know? You weren't in total control of your masquerade? Some energies leaked out and created images from our minds.
KRO'KA: No, I, well, they were.
TIGGER: Kro'Ka, Kro'Ka, you've done it again. You've messed about with equipment you're not quite sure how to use. Pinched it again too, I'll bet. Ow! Am I getting on your nerves? I've been told it's something I'm very good at. You are trying to mop up the mess you've made by letting me get to this planet. That is a guess, but it's spot on, isn't it. You're really extraordinarily incompetent. Why did the Divergents even take you on in the first place. Argh! Will you stop that? I have a good deal more to say and you're interrupting the flow. There's Time on this planet somewhere, and it can't be the Divergents. Well, at least it can't be if that stuff about the castle was true, and I believe it was. You were very frightened when you told me. So, if it's not the Divergents producing these tiny breezes of Time, very refreshing they are too, what is? In this universe, there are only four possibilities. The Divergents themselves, Rassilon, if he's still around, me, and the Tardis.
KRO'KA: Very good, Doctor. Top marks.
TIGGER: Where is it?
KRO'KA: That's my secret, Doctor.
TIGGER: Tell me where it is.
KRO'KA: I think not.
TIGGER: Now remember what I
KRO'KA: Oh, yes. You'll tell on me to the Divergents, like a tattling school boy. But you're not going to be in any condition to meet them.
TIGGER: Those unpleasant plans of yours.
KRO'KA: Exactly.
TIGGER: Let's get back to the subject. My Tardis. It's where, exactly?
KRO'KA: Why should I tell you?
TIGGER: Just to be nice?
KRO'KA: I am not the nice one here, Doctor. You are. Your sense of decency will not allow you to harm me, so there's no way to make me reveal the location of your Tardis.
TIGGER: I er. No, you have me there.
KRO'KA: And here.
TIGGER: Argh! Listen, Kro'Ka, I say this not as an enemy but as a, well, yes, as an enemy but as a friendly one. Have you ever heard of anger management classes? Ow! I think I'll just sit down on the floor for a moment.
KRO'KA: How satisfying to see you grovel, Doctor.
TIGGER: I'm not grovelling, I'm merely sitting here. Well, lying here, catching my breath.
KRO'KA: Still, you are at my feet.
TIGGER: You don't have feet. Ow! All right, we'll define a foot as anything that can kick.
KRO'KA: How puny and breakable you are.
TIGGER: As you already realised that, there's really no reason to try to prove it. We'll just agree that under your ministrations I would turn to jelly, then go our separate ways, two creatures with different philosophies but a commonality of. Oh well, hang on a minute. We must have something in common. Let's see. We both breath.
KRO'KA: How much I shall enjoy shutting your babbling mouth.
TIGGER: I don't believe that. You like having someone to listen to. It's a lonely life, isn't it, Kro'Ka? Where are the rest of your people? Are you an exile? The way you sneak around on the Divergents, I can't think you serve them all that willingly.
KRO'KA: You don't know what you're talking about.
TIGGER: Yes, I do. I may talk like a fool, but I always know what I'm talking like a fool about. I think you're as lost and cut off from your home as I am. How long have you been alone? Do you have a dream about the past, and then wake up aching because you know it's gone forever? Argh! Kro'Ka, listen. Urgh!
KRO'KA: No more talking, Doctor. It's time to go back to work.

elements.text: PART FOUR
Horsedrawn vehicles and voices.
All right, that's it. It's been nearly half an hour. Let's go.
Where?
Well, if he's not here yet, he's not coming. He needs help.
How do you know?

Because sooner or later, he almost always does. He attracts danger. It's as if there's something in him that draws problems close so that he can fix them. I think he knew he was headed into the thick of things and didn't tell us so we wouldn't get hurt. Drives me crazy when he does that. I keep telling him not to, but he gets all protective.
You, er, care a lot about each other.
Yes?
Are you in love?
It's not like that. I mean, we love each other, but. Oh, it's difficult to explain.
Like an Obelat.
Rotten analogy, C'Rizz.
Love's always dangerous. (sotto) Just ask L'Da.
Don't any of these streets go in a straight line?
Apparently not. All we seem to do is turn corners.
Well, just keep an eye on that tower. That looks as thought it ought to be an official building. As long as we head towards it, we're all right.
It Keeps moving. I mean, we keep moving and then I lose track of it. And when I see it again, it's not where I expected. Oh, speaking of which.
Oh, bother. Where's it gone now?
Did it drop behind a roof?
I don't think we've gone downhill enough for that to happen. Oh, well, enough of this. I'm going to ask directions.
How? We don't know their language.
Well then, I'll gesture very precisely.
Oh, and they'll gesture back.
They'll point. They will helpfully point and we'll go that way.
Around another corner.
I could use a bit of support here.
I'm merely saying that
Oi! I mean, ahem, excuse me, but can you tell. Oh. How rude.
He just walked away.
Pardon me, sir, but we were wondering whether. Oh, well thanks. Very helpful.
Maybe he didn't hear you. Let me try. Hello? As you can see, I'm an alien lost on your planet. What's wrong with them?
Perhaps we're on the planet of the deaf.
Then what do they have ears for. And look, they're talking to each other.
Oh, this is ridiculous. What do you have to do to get their attention, set yourself on fire?
You could try jumping up and down.
I want them to notice us, not think we're mad.
I'll jump with you.
(laughs) You're trying to be supportive now, aren't you.
Er, yes.
That's very sweet of you, but if they're likely to think I'm mad jumping up and down, what will they think if we both do?
Yes, all right. Actually, I'm surprised they're not all staring at me. I mean, I must look unusual.
Now that is rude of them.
Yes. Perhaps they're simply trying to pretend I'm not here?

Ah yes, don't want to disrupt their comfortable lives by admitting there might actually be someone alien in their midst. (shouts) I'm an alien, too! I'm from another planet. I'm from another universe!
Oh. Oh, that'll assure them.
Support, C'Rizz.
It doesn't matter, anyway. Nobody's taking any notice. They're just going to ignore us.
Unless. See, ooo, I don't know. Her.
Hmm?
The woman with the basket of rolls. I'm going to jump right in front of her.
No, Charlotte, wait.
Woo! There, see? She didn't even register me, but she stepped out of the way. don't think they're actually seeing us.
Or hearing us. All right. They can sense when they have to avoid colliding with us, but they seem to do that subconsciously.
To them, we're not here. Only we are here, so
They're not.
If they're illusions, why take the trouble not to bump into us? We must be shielded from them somehow.
But when the Doctor ran off, he was dodging through them and apologising.
And not noticing if anyone responded, so he wouldn't have thought it odd. And that's not like him.
It's like this him. He's impulsive, full of sudden enthusiasms.

Well, that is like him, actually, only not all the time. I was trying to tell him that what's happened is that bits of his personality have chipped off, so that we have a sort of bouncy pixilated one, and a sane reasonable one, and er, the other.
Oh yes, you went exploring with him, didn't you. What's he like?
He'd be greatly improved if something heavy dropped on him.
Oh. Oh look, the tower's visible again.
So it is. We must have been walking uphill. It didn't feel like it, though. I've just been following you all this time. You've been acting as if you've some idea where to go.
I've been following this.
What, is that string?
Don't you remember? The Doctor tied one end of it to his belt before he left.
No wonder we haven't found our way to the administration building. You've been sending us twisting around after this silly string.
The Doctor is on the other end of this string.
The Doctor was going to the administration building.
Obviously not.
We don't know that this string's still attached to him. It might have ended up tied to a passing cart or something.
How would that have happened?
Well, all right, it's unlikely. But if we are following the Doctor, why isn't he going where he said he was?
Well, he may be. Even though it doesn't look like it, this may be the most direct route. In any case, what we want to find is the Doctor, wherever he is.
Lead on.
We should go (pause) this way.
Around another corner.
Hmm. There aren't anything but corners.
I know I hate to point it out. The tower's out of sight again.
You were saying something earlier about support?

Sorry. Oh, this place is beginning to get on my nerves. I feel as if we're in a jigsaw puzzle, where someone's spilled all the pieces then put them back together wrong. I mean, every planet has its peculiarities, but this one doesn't even seem to match up with itself.
Internally inconsistent.

Exactly. There's a zoological park full of oddities, a maze with a minotaur, and a giant cuckoo clock with no hands, and people who can't tell we're here, all jammed together. Not to mention that all the roads and paths and walls appear to converge.
If that's the case, then we're bound to come to the administration centre sooner or later.
Oh, good point.
These people still aren't noticing us.
I think I'm right about a shield.
Who has constructed it? None of the Doctors believe the Divergents are here.
Oh, heaven knows. It's just one more puzzle in this. Hello! That's the administration building, isn't it? But we've come up to it from behind.
The string goes in that window. Do you suppose the Doctor sneaked in? How could he get up there?
Oh, he has his methods. But the way things shift around here, that may well have once been the main entrance.
Well, as we can't get to the window ourselves, I suggest we go round to the present main entrance.
Agreed. Oh, I hope we can find it without. Oh! Here it is.
Just round the corner of the wall.
I suppose we didn't come at it from behind after all, or we did, and
The walls moved.
A bit of stability would be nice at this point.
You'll be lucky. The steps seem solid enough.
Very official looking doors. Most impressive.
And most unlocked.
Open to the public. How terribly democratic.
Door opens.
Looks ordinary enough. Awfully empty though.
Wait. A bit of caution, perhaps? After all, this place is probably full of surprises.
You think this could be a trap?
It's worth considering.
Hmm. We need a decoy. Let's see if I have anything on me. Oh, the candle holder. Well, I won't be needing that again. Right, here goes.
Plink of metal on stone floor. Thump! They jump.
That was an extremely large trap door.
And what do you bet it's opened above an extremely long drop. I think back to the window, don't you?
Running.
I hope it's in the same place.
We're in luck. It's still here. Unfortunately, it's still as high. Do you think you could climb that tree, go out on that branch and leap inside?
Er, no.
Sure?
Quite sure. I don't like heights.
Oh, you big brave soldier, you. But there's no harm in me trying.
There's quite a bit of harm in you trying, actually. You might fall.
Oh, I'm a champion faller. You should have seen me in that clock. Oh, come on. Give me a leg up.

Charlotte, please show some sense. You can see from here it won't work. But nothing says we have to go in that particular window. Look, if we note where the one we enter through is in relation to this one, we should be able to locate the string from inside.
You're right, you're right. I was just being silly. It's just I'm a little more adventurous, it seems.
Well, come on then, Miss Little More Adventurous, let's search for a lower window.
Well, here we are again, doomed to certain death. It's becoming tiresome. More of the same, and then more more of the same.
It's not getting any closer.
Well, that's something. Do we have anything we can use to defend ourselves?
Balls of string.
Not much help there.
No, not really, no, but did you see it earlier, this monster?
No.
Charley did. She says it's a minotaur.
But that's
Yes.
They're taking images from our minds
And Charley's, and C'Rizz's. It's certainly possible for this culture to have mazes, but I suspect this one is drawn from our knowledge of Greek myths.
Some things are askew, like that clock without hands. Illusions?
I think constructs, don't you? Artificial but material.
Yes, that would make more sense. In that case
Roar!
Oh dear. What do you suppose would happen when construct met construct?
Let's find out. Stand against the wall. Good. When it charges, we leap to the side.
I'm not convinced this is the ideal
Very close roar, then a hiss.
What do you know, right through the wall.
It must have reconstituted itself on the other side.
I wonder where it is now?
Who can tell? Space is so fluid here, everywhere seems to be somewhere else as well.
There's just the barest possibility. No, the wall is solid for us. Shame.
Start walking?
Start walking.
Now, if we're on the right track, and I believe we are, then we should come to
Look! The string's running out from under that door. Oh, superb navigating, C'Rizz.
Thank you.
Now it goes down this staircase. Marble. This is elegant. Hey, you'd look good with a nice marble effect skin. Can you do that? Go on, you know you want to.
Maybe later. And more importantly, the stairs might lead to one of the public spaces.
Walk down stairs.
You never know. Still think you'd look good all marbley.
I heard that. Eutermesan ears, you know. I was right about the stairs. Look, the main doors. We're coming down to the atrium.
Floor's back in place, I see. And there's the end of the string in the middle of it. We've lost him.
Only temporarily, I'm sure. Hmm, I wonder if that floor's safe now.
We don't know where to begin to search. Oh, we may as well go back upstairs, and then, when we get to the hall we'll start methodically.
Run up stairs.
What happened to the hall?
It's turned into more of your precious marble steps, only these ones go down.
Oh, honestly. Well, nothing to do but continue. What are you doing?
Look at the ceiling.
More stairs?
That's absurd. We must be looking at the underside of a staircase on the next storey.
But they're carpeted.
All right, there's a staircase on the ceiling. Doubtless some architectural innovation native to this society. And very innovative it is. Useless, of course, but an interesting concept.
I think we'd better just deal with these steps we're on. Who knows what they'll decide to do. They could go up again, or sideways.
Or lead right into a wall.
Oh, blast! Well, we'll just have to retrace. Oi, where's the staircase?
It's becoming very tiresome.

Well, that's one word for it. Well, at least we have a hall to go along, and plenty of doors on either side. Hmm, let's see. This one's empty, and this one's an office. No one in it, though, and another empty office.
I'll take the other side.
Office, office, oh, and guess what.
An office?
No, a room full of lavatory paper.
Then where is everyone? This place should be full of, well, whoever lives in offices, I suppose.
Boring men in suits, and prim and proper secretaries.
Well, no one's around.
Well, that's one bit of luck, then. Right, more stairs through this door.
New stairs?
Yes. Let's go.
But where do they lead?
Out of this place, I hope. Come on.
Not very interesting, is it.
No.
All the dangers I've faced, I never thought I'd die of boredom.
Oh, we'll die of thirst first.
Cheerful.
Doctor!
Charley!
What are you doing here?
Follow me. I've left C'Rizz holding the door open.
How did you find a door?
Well, we were upstairs, wandering through the hallways and not finding you, so I opened an office door at random and instead of an office there was a flight of stairs.
And they lead directly here?
Isn't that strange? We keep coming in different ways and meeting one another. The maze is everywhere and the administration building is everywhere.
And the castle
Is everywhere. The fortress of the turning powers. This is Caerdroia.
Wake up, Doctor. I want you conscious for this.
Oh, you're still here. I hoped it was a nightmare.
It soon will be.

Mmm, no racks, no hot pokers, no iron maidens. All to the good. Only walls of ooo, I'm impressed. That's some very sophisticated looking machinery. How intriguing. I don't suppose you'd unstrap me, let me have a closer look? No, I didn't think so. So what next? Want to visit my mind again? The welcome mat is out, the door is always open.
I'm not going to enter your mind. I will draw information from it.
I see. Not the mind nudge, but the brain drain.
It will hurt.
Yes, you'd rather implied that. Will I survive?
Yes, but you'll wish you hadn't.
Oh, stop being fiendish and get on with it. What is it, anyway? How does the process work?
Curious to the end.
Well, as I'm not going to have my mind much longer, I'd like to use it while I still can.
You know, Doctor, I admire you.
Really? Thank you.

You have courage and integrity. You fight evil fiercely but are capable of mercy. To save a universe you chose permanent exile from everything you knew and at the cost of one of your senses. You are truly heroic.
Pity to destroy me, then.
It is a necessity to destroy you. You threaten all the Divergent's plans.

Which are what, exactly? Who am I going to tell? My mind will be mush. Come on. The last request. All right, all right. All right, fine. Then you can at least explain what you're going to do with me. It's only fair. How does this thingy work?

There's no need to go into complexities. All you have to know is that the wires will penetrate your brain and draw out your memories. They will be stored, then the Divergents will scan them for the secrets of the Tardis.
All of my memories? That's several hundred years worth, you know. Couldn't you just take information about the Tardis?
Unfortunately the instruments are not that precise.

That's an extraordinary amount of scanning. I'm surprised the Divergents have time for such menial tasks. Why don't you simply edit the memories for them first? I mean, surely you know how to do that? After all, you must have followed the similar work going on in Light City. And what did you get from Setarus? Three versions of the same mind, Major Koth's. And what do we have here? Three versions of me. I'd say you've been paying very careful attention, Kro'Ka, wouldn't you?
Shut up! I will not be able to access those memories. Only the Divergents can.
So they'll have to search all of my memory.
Yes.
Including the part about your stealing the mind probe and then not knowing how to use it, and then letting me escape to the planet where the Tardis is.
I will, I will tell them I brought you here only to break into the Tardis.

What about the first two mistakes? Are you hiding from the Divergents, Kro'Ka? Hmm? You must be. If they had any idea what you were doing, they'd squash you flat as a pancake. You know about pancakes? Breakfast item, extremely flat. Somehow you're shielding yourself from your actions, desperately trying to set things straight before your next report. I don't think you want the Divergents anywhere near my memories, or me, for that matter. Bit of a dilemma for you. If you make sure they never find me, they won't like it. And if they find me, and interrogate me, they won't like it. Squashed, either way.
I will kill you.
(scoffs) Don't be silly. They really won't like that. Now unstrap me, like a good fellow. Ow!
You have destroyed me, Doctor.

Not really. I just waited around for you to destroy yourself. I knew that eventually you'd be hoist on your own petard. Most people don't understand that properly, by the way. A petard is a sort of land mine, not a spear.
Will you shut up!
You don't want me to shut up. I can tell you how to save yourself.
How?
Just tell me what the Divergents are up to, and how to find them. That's all. I'll stop them soon enough. You know I can, you said so yourself. Ow!
There are less complicated ways to get information from you, and I will get it. Long before I finish, you'll wish I'd ruined only your mind.
Door closes.
We shall see, Doctor. I'll find out exactly how much pain you can endure.
Not a lot, actually.
Doctor!
A hangnail pretty much reduces me to tears. By the way, I couldn't help overhearing. Are you planning to torture me?
How did you escape the labyrinth?
There is no labyrinth. Or rather, the labyrinth is also these hallways, and somehow, I imagine, all the roads in the town eventually lead here. Where are they?
Who?
The Divergents, Kro'Ka. I Know they're here. We're on Caerdroia.
You're mistaken.
Where are they hiding? Or is it you whose hiding, right under their noses until you can get me sorted out and save your life?
It is your life you should worry about, Doctor.
I think not. Your masters want me alive.
There are still the other two.
Running.
I will catch you and crush you, Doctor!
No, thank you. Stairs. Well, better up than down.
I will make you sorry you ever came to this universe!
I'm already sorry. I was sorry the moment I arrived.
There is no way out!
Except this convenient door.
Into the clock tower.
You're trapped, Doctor. I've locked you in. Now let the vibrations in the bells do their work! You will tell me everything then.
The Doctor screams as the peal of church bells sounds.
I have them both. I can make one of them talk. I know I can make one of them talk.
Will I do?
Am I never to be free of you?
No. I'm everywhere, like the castle.
You have no time to waste on me. You must save your other selves.
Exactly what I plan to do. Let's see. You have two of us, the responsible one and the loony one. That leave me. Which one do you think I am?
I, I
I'm the nasty one.
Absurd! You are the Doctor! Your reputation is
Well, it isn't precisely my reputation, is it? Two of me are missing from the mix. Lovely chaps, both of them. Decent, honourable, compassionate. No wonder they're in
trouble. They keep a sharp eye on me, step in when I'm likely to get up to mischief. Only they're not here now.
Don't bluff me, Doctor. I am your physical superior
Arguable.
And you are ethically incapable.
Why are you backing away like that if you say I can't hurt you?
What are you
I only want to place my hand here.
Do not touch
Against your temple.
Ah!
You're in my mind.
The others never allow me to invade a mind. Perhaps they have a point. It's a dump.
Please, please, please.
Painful, isn't it. You might remember that the next time you plan to take a stroll round someone's cerebellum.
What, what do you want?
What do you think I want! The others, of course. Where have you put them?
I won't tell you. You can't stay here and bully me. You'll have to search for them.
I'll stay here as long as I please. There's no particular reason to hurry, unless you happen to be torturing them. I'll just bet you are. It's so much your style. Clich√©d and ugly. Where are they?
One is in pain and the other soon will be! You'd better leave now, Doctor, if you want to help them.
You haven't been listening, Kro'Ka. Which one am I?
Kro'Ka screams.
Which one am I?
You are still the Doctor. You will not
Oh, Kro'Ka. Don't be silly. Of course I will.
Kro'Ka screams.
Now I want to know where they are. Do you think I can persuade you to tell me?
(singing) Fourteen bottles of beer on the wall, fourteen bottles of beer. Take one down, drink it down, thirteen bottles of beer on the wall.
Door opens.
Thirteen bottles of beer
You can shut up.
I'm glad you're here. I started at five hundred bottles, and things were getting a bit stale.
What's all this equipment? Don't tell me he was going to use the brain drain on you. What an embarrassing way to die.
Would you please unstrap me? Where are the others?
Wandering the halls, I expect. Not much else to do here. We need to get to the other one as well. He's in an extremely unpleasant situation.
How did you find me? Where's Kro'Ka? Oh, yes. Oh dear. You ought
Don't go all morally superior on me. I'm part of you. Remember that.
Yes, I'm afraid you are.
There, that's done it. Come on.
Church bells pealing.
What was that? You're repeating the code. What are you saying? What are you trying to tell me?
All the doors lead to stairs.
Oh, how are we ever going to find him?
Hello. Good to see you.
Follow me.
You know where they are?
Why do you think I said follow me. Now follow me.
Where have you been?
Nowhere nice. Here, this is the door.
Door opens. Distant church bells.
I really hope we're not up there.
Running up stairs.
Oh, this bolt is stuck.
Here.
Heaves. Door opens.
There he is.
Oh, grab his arms, pull him out.
It's all right, Charley, he's alive.
Door closes.
Let's get him downstairs. He's trying to say something.
Get him into the hall, lay him on the floor.
Is he all right?
He appears to be. He's not very articulate just yet.
Spoke to me.
The bells?
The Tardis.
What? What did she tell you?
I'm not certain. I only have part of it. She's giving me directions, but I can't tell from where to where.
Oh.
Care to clue us in?
The Tardis did it.
No clearer, is it.
It wasn't the result of coming through the portal. The Tardis split us in three.
What for?
Of course. What a fool I've been. Charley, remember the chimes in the clock?
What, the chimes that shouldn't have been there?
The musical brook in the garden.
Even the cow bells. That's why they were following us.
The Tardis was using them to transmit her own vibrations, trying to speak to us.
She couldn't convey her whole message in only one pitch and tone through only one instrument. There had to be enough of us to spread out to be sure of getting all the pieces.
CHARLEY And now you have, now what?
I suppose we'll have to commune mentally. This jumping in and out of other people's minds is beginning to get on my nerves.
But this will be your mind.
Even worse. How would you like to go somewhere different and be in the same place, or stay in the same place and be somewhere different. It's very disorienting.
But rather fun.
Please be quiet.
Gentlemen, please. This dissension is unseemly. We are, after all, a unit. Now, let's fall into the same trance.
When they're still like that, they look eerie. Even more alike than twins.
It's because they're not twins or triplets. Something much more basic.
Oh.
I see!
Let's go.
Footsteps.
Oi, hang on! What was the message?

Sorry. It's very useful, actually. The Tardis is in the centre of the labyrinth. And as that would be rather difficult to find, the whole idea of a labyrinth being that you're not er, no, no, sorry, that's a maze. Well, in any case, as that would be difficult.
She's told us how to get there.
Well put.
I never, I never thought that you could find that. I never.
Roar! Kro'Ka screams and squishes as a double beat sounds in the background.
I have to go. We have to go. That creature. I never knew a duplicate could hurt me.
Hurt you? I should hope so. you've broken our contract, spoiled our plan.
Sir, please, I've not, actually. Argh!
Listen to me very carefully, Kro'Ka. Wheels are in motion here. Events far more important that you and your schemes. We had a deal, and you broke it. I fear I must now break you.
No, no, argh!
Running.
She's here!
Oh, I was afraid I'd never see her again.
You needn't stare. The Tardis really is here.
Yes, you're right. No need to be sentimental. Who has the key?
I think we all do.
Tardis door unlocked.
What are you waiting for?
Well, goodbye. Goodbye, old chap. Lovely to have met you. Goodbye C'Rizz, Charley.
What do you mean? Will you recombine once you enter the Tardis?
I'm fairly certain
Then don't lag about.
Oi, don't push him. Oh, he's gone.
They're both gone.
[OC]: Come in, you two.
Tardis door closes.
